Brian Clough.Action: Sings cheerfully with his sons in the car, engages them with excitement about the stadium.
Smiles with his sons at the stadium, showing a moment of shared joy.
Drives past the stadium his sons were excited about, ignoring their disappointment.
Confidently approaches Leeds United stadium but deliberately drives past the turning, indicating he has a plan beyond the obvious move.
Laughs along with the TV crew's humor when asked about his past criticisms.
Openly admits to his criticisms of Leeds players and their tactics.
Talks confidently about his new role, showing no hesitation or doubt.
Says footballers are sensitive people and expresses desire to bring warmth into the set-up.
Acknowledges initial strangeness and expects resentment but describes himself as fair and kind and wants the team to feel like a happy family.
Greets players cheerfully despite the cold, makes a light joke about the weather, laughs openly.
Players respond with silence and disrespect; Clough does not react negatively or harshly.
Confidently greets the players and attempts to use humor to break the ice despite the cold, dreary conditions and hostile atmosphere.
Fails to elicit any positive reaction or engagement from the players, who remain surly and disrespectful.
Addresses the cold reception without bitterness, attempts light humor ('Great. Here's to happy fucking families.')
Informally greets Don Revie's secretary as 'duck' and requests a cup of tea, suggesting ease and friendliness
Smiles sweetly and tries to defuse the situation by offering tea.
Refuses to let the board meeting interrupt his moment, showing a casual friendliness.
Dismisses the secretary Jean Reid abruptly and insists on her resignation without gentle explanation.
Uses a mocking tone about Don Revie’s desk and presence, causing visible distress to Jean Reid.
Puts arms protectively around the boys, leading them out safely.
Refuses to immediately attend the board meeting despite being called, preferring to delay and assert control.
Decides to remove the predecessor's desk and chairs to erase the old regime's influence.
Dismisses Jean Reid curtly, telling her to resign and change the locks, firmly securing his authority.
Uses protective body language around his sons while confronting Jean Reid.
Jokes about the lack of hospitality ('What? No one going to offer me a drink? Like an undertakers in here.'), attempting to lighten the mood.
Defends his critical interview about the players and Don Revie, showing a confrontational and unapologetic stance.
Thanks Cussins sincerely when praised, showing some humility and friendliness.
Enters the boardroom confidently, takes the seat at the head of the table, jokes about the formality of the setting.
Defends himself firmly and unflinchingly when questioned about the controversial TV interview and his critical quotes about the players.
Shows awareness and acceptance of criticism by others but remains unapologetic and assertive about his own opinions.
Engages in mild banter and self-praise when told he is the best young manager; possibly shows confidence but risks seeming arrogant.
Declares his obsession with beating Don Revie and claims he will not rest until he does, using aggressive and confrontational language.
Expresses intense loyalty and passion for his club and city, showing sincere personal investment.
Refers disparagingly to the elders of Leeds, mocking them with racialized and demeaning language ('big white faces', 'stinking jars').
Shows excitement and shared enjoyment with others when Derby County is drawn in the FA Cup, engaging warmly with those around him at home.
Responds to chairman's support by arranging a special meal for his family and expresses general excitement about it.
Takes a practical yet considerate approach to improving the facilities for visiting players by addressing worn signage and woodwork.
Immediately recognizes the challenge of playing against top team Leeds United and responds with confident enthusiasm.
Takes the chairman's support seriously and translates it into positive morale with his family and team.
Shows attention to detail and care by instructing maintenance workers to improve facilities for visiting players, demonstrating organization and professionalism.
Commands cleaners to make everything spick and span, insisting on proper polish and care.
Inspects pitch and demands perfection to suit quality footballers.
Recalls growing up near Don Revie, mentioning childhood neighborhood and his father’s workplace, showing a personal connection.
Commands the cleaners to thoroughly clean and polish the facilities, demanding 'spick and span' conditions.
Inspects the pitch and demands it to be perfect, 'like a fucking carpet', showing attention to detail and high standards.
Ignores practical advice that the pitch is untrainable in current condition; insists on unrealistic standards.
Is aware of rival manager Don Revie's meticulous preparation and analysis methods, demonstrating strategic awareness.
Relies on personal and anecdotal knowledge about Don Revie instead of focusing solely on professional tactics.
Arrives early, performing humble tasks like sweeping corridors, straightening photos and signs, and scrubbing visiting team’s washroom baths.
Sets up vintage wine and two glasses for himself and rival Don Revie, making a sincere effort to welcome the opposing manager.
Compliments Don Revie openly, calling them 'two peas in a pod' despite their rivalry.
Walks out first to greet the arriving team, straightening his appearance, extending hand to greet Don Revie.
Stares in disbelief after Don Revie ignores his outstretched hand and walks past without greeting.
Rushes out first to greet the arriving team, appearing eager and confident to engage with opponents.
Extends hand to Don Revie in a gesture of sportsmanship and confidence but is ignored, causing visible disbelief and fixation on the slight.
Unable to let go of Revie's insult, staring and distracted when he should be focusing on the game and team.
Screams in outrage and protests penalty decision he believes is unjust against his team.
Focuses intently on rival manager Revie and his celebratory behavior rather than supporting or encouraging his own players during the match.
Leaps off the bench in outrage, protesting a penalty decision that he believes is wrong.
Stares at Revie and his team applauding cynical play without responding or directing his own team.
Fails to join his assistants in giving tactical instructions during the match.
Expresses disappointment that opposing players did not stay to show respect or share a drink after the match.
Focuses on motivating Taylor by emphasizing the need to beat the rival team and recruit an experienced player, showing trust and delegation.
Expresses determination to beat Leeds despite the defeat, plans proactively to strengthen the team by instructing Taylor to find an experienced player.
Seems emotionally affected and distracted after the loss, not responding to Taylor's comment about the referee and opponents (ignores immediate context).
Attempts to engage the Leeds players positively by clapping and gathering them together.
Harshly criticizes the players for cheating and tells them to discard their medals and achievements.
Addresses captain Billy Bremner as a good player and sets clear expectations for clean and attractive football.
Takes charge confidently by addressing the Leeds players directly despite their truculence, showing readiness to confront a difficult situation.
Demands players discard their medals and trophies won unfairly, indicating a strong moral stance but risking alienating experienced, successful players.
Focuses on practical team needs by emphasizing the importance of keeping captain Bremner fit and setting a good example, showing strategic and managerial awareness.
Addresses players directly with critical but constructive feedback, sets clear expectations for behavior, emphasizes respect and professionalism.
Uses sarcastic and somewhat mocking nicknames (e.g., 'Bites yer Legs') and is confrontational towards players' past conduct.
Encourages players to become 'worthy champions' and appeals to their legacy and reputation, motivating them to improve positively.
Dismisses previous manager Don and forbids mention of his name, potentially alienating players loyal to Don.
Enforces discipline by threatening players who mention Don or dwell on the past; insists on keeping the game clean and sensible.
Leads by example by playing himself in a seven-a-side game despite being a manager; displays confidence in his skills.
Encourages and coaches players during the game, giving friendly, direct instructions.
Refuses to back down from a strong tackle, showing toughness but not concession or friendliness in the confrontation.
Insists on no fifty-fifty challenges, showing clear standards and leadership.
Volleys and controls the ball skillfully, demonstrating football skill.
Takes the field himself when a side is short, leading by example.
Refuses to pull out of a fifty-fifty challenge despite orders, resulting in a hard tackle and injury.
Jimmy Gordon brings his sons to him, and Clough acknowledges Jimmy as 'Good lad.'
Holds his sons watching him destroy Don Revie's desk with an axe in anger.
Is visibly in agony and disrespected by opponents but does not retaliate physically against players.
Lies on the floor holding his knee in agony, showing physical vulnerability during a confrontation.
Listens to players laughing and mocking him, his face darkens but he does not retaliate or assert control.
Takes possession of a parcel and confirms its contents and location, showing awareness and preparation.
Storms into Don Revie's office, violently destroys the desk with an axe, then watches it burn in a bonfire, demonstrating decisive and confrontational action.
People scatter when he limps down the corridor in a thunderous mood, indicating he commands respect or fear despite physical limitation.
Avoids replying to Barbara's calls, stays away from the dining room despite her asking him to come back.
Spends time with Taylor after missing Sunday lunch with family; appears happier in Taylor's company than with family, engaging in childlike activities such as eating crisps and sweets.
Waits until morning to talk to Longson despite an urgent issue with a managerial offer from Hearts.
Demonstrates awareness that the deal is not fully signed, showing understanding of negotiation status.
Shares a playful moment with Taylor, giggling like kids about a tie shop.
Insists on completing a signing despite possible illegality and risks letting the opposition gain advantage the next day.
Confidently approaches Dave Mackay at his home unannounced to recruit him for Derby County, using humor and charm.
Ignores protocol by going over the chairman's head without prior notice, risking managerial discord.
Reassures the chairman about a player's fitness despite skepticism, displaying confidence and trust in his judgement.
Smiles while explaining his decisions and introduces new signings warmly, shows friendly and sincere behavior.
Takes credit for signing players without prior consultation, leading to confrontation from the chairman, indicating disregard for others' authority.
Watches the team play with admiration and praises his assistant Pete Taylor warmly and sincerely.
Insists on signing a player despite opposition, showing confidence based on trusted advice.
Brings in McGovern and O'Hare from his old area as reasonable signings, demonstrating strategic recruitment.
Smiles confidently and states acting in best interest of the club despite chairman's objections.
Grabs Taylor's head and kisses him, showing open affection.
Sings a Sinatra classic humorously to Peter Taylor at a celebratory family gathering, amusing others.
Watches Mackay passing the ball, appreciating the skill and strategy; calls it 'a thing of fucking beauty'.
Leaps to his feet celebrating goals scored by Derby in multiple matches.
Sings a lighthearted song to Peter Taylor, not his own wife, amusing everyone.
Watches Don Revie's award presentation, then encourages Revie to enjoy it with a mix of cynicism and quiet confidence, ending with a collective cheer.
Confidently declares his team's intent to reach the First Division and compete against Don Revie, showing ambition and determination.
His strong, focused gaze at Don Revie on TV implies a strategic mindset and competitive awareness.
Encourages team to show new attitude, play with a smile, and adopts a positive, motivational tone before the match.
Quietly chooses to continue with Billy Bremner as club captain despite Bremner's silence, showing trust and respect.
Gives a clear team lineup and sets expectations for a new attitude, discipline, and approach before his first game at Leeds.
Folds a piece of paper with a flicker of vulnerability showing some insecurity before the match.
Attempts to assert his leadership by confirming club captaincy with Billy Bremner but receives silence in response.
Expresses high regard and sincere admiration for Bremner by writing a personal card inviting him and his family to visit.
Bremner never received the card Clough claims to have sent.
Expresses high regard for Bremner as a player, sends a personal card inviting him and his family, showing thoughtfulness and a strategic attempt to build rapport.
Bremner never receives the card, indicating a failure in communication or follow-through.
Leads his players confidently out onto the Wembley pitch in front of 67,000 fans, maintaining composure and focus.
Expresses frustration and disappointment at team violence, especially directed at his captain Billy Bremner, showing care and concern for his players.
Mocks the situation with sarcasm ('Because losing wasn't enough, was it?'), potentially showing impatience and critical tone.
Criticizes players openly and sharply, focusing on their failures without visible empathy.
Engages in candid, direct conversation with Taylor, willing to confront issues bluntly.
Shows enthusiasm and openness to recruiting a new player to improve the team despite financial concerns.
Realistically assesses team's poor performance against Leeds and identifies specific weaknesses (e.g., O'Hare being bullied, McGovern ineffective in midfield).
Decides promptly to sign a desired player (Colin Todd) to improve the team despite financial constraints mentioned by Taylor.
Dismisses financial concerns ('Bollocks to that...') expressed by Longson regarding signing players, possibly showing either confident determination or reckless disregard for club finances.
Firmly defends signing Colin Todd as a top player despite financial concerns, asserting his vision for the club.
Corrects and mocks Sam Longson’s objections sarcastically, calls Todd 'the ALMIGHTY Colin Todd'.
Acknowledges loyalty of Sam Longson and others while negotiating tensions.
Ignores Sam Longson’s anger and threats, prioritizing football business over deference.
Insists on signing Colin Todd despite financial concerns and opposition, showing confidence in his evaluation of the player's technical skills.
Takes initiative to handle negotiations directly, bypassing authority to seize opportunities.
Confronts opposition from club officials with composed and strategic responses.
Disregards financial prudence leading to tension with club officials.
Firmly tells the Chairman to leave football management to professionals and focus on his business, using dismissive and confrontational language ('there's a good lad')
Assertively challenges the Chairman and insists on professional management of the club, emphasizing ambition to be the best and asking for financial support.
Shows confidence and clarity in his vision for the club, indicating understanding of football management.
Dismisses Chairman's authority in a confrontational and disrespectful manner.
Encourages John McGovern warmly, praises his hard work and tells him to enjoy the game.
Supports John O'Hare by endorsing a tough, retaliatory approach to bullying and giving clear tactical advice.
Engages with new signing Colin Todd by recalling his confidence and sharing in the dressing-room laughter.
Shakes each player's hand as they leave the dressing room.
Carries brandy into the dressing room and pours drinks for players despite the poor performance.
Mocks and sarcastically congratulates players on terrible football, implying they want to get him sacked.
Directly accuses players of deliberately missing goals to get him sacked, showing suspicion and distrust.
Hands a cup to player Colin Todd in a somewhat sarcastic manner, then forces players to drink an entire bottle before the second half, using pressure.
Faces the room and acknowledges the players have 'done a terrific job' of getting him sacked, then insists on drinking together, attempting camaraderie though in a forceful way.
Winks defiantly at Peter Taylor after being confronted about his harsh approach, showing defiance rather than empathy.
Visibly anxious and pacing restlessly, showing emotional investment and vulnerability like an expectant father.
Runs towards Peter Taylor with eager recognition and mutual silent understanding, displaying a close, trusting bond.
Paces anxiously in his office, visibly anxious and unable to watch the game directly, but maintains composure by slowing down from running to walking with dignity.
Opens the door and walks quickly but with dignity to find out the result rather than remaining passive or uninformed.
Exchanges a meaningful, confident look with Peter Taylor, communicating effectively without words.
Embraces Taylor warmly after the win and shares a friendly interaction celebrating the player's performance.
Shows understanding of players' nervousness ('They were just nervous. Shitting themselves. You could tell.'), indicating empathy and insight.
Celebrates Derby County's championship victory by praising decency, honesty, and fair play in football.
Publicly disparages rival teams, especially Leeds United, accusing them of dirty play and implying a need to punish them by relegation.
Appears as a charismatic and witty media star, engaging with the press in a playful but confrontational manner.
Admits to disliking a talented man despite acknowledging his abilities; acknowledges differing opinions in football and politics.
Responds to criticism of being big-headed and arrogant with humor and some humility.
Sits at home with his son on his lap, expressing delight that 'the good guys win for once.'
Expresses frustration towards a chairman for not supporting the team financially, criticizing chairmen as detrimental to the game.
Reflects on winning important matches and shows confidence in his football knowledge and achievements.
Expresses frustration about lack of financial support from chairman despite clear goals and ambition.
Expresses deep love and passion for football, talks openly about his enthusiasm and honesty.
Admits he talks too much but appreciates honesty and truth.
Responds to criticism by inviting discussion but ultimately insists he was right.
Acknowledges he talks too much but also asserts his knowledge confidently when challenged, engaging in reasoned debate about how things should be done.
Expresses deep passion for football and honesty in his communication, showing emotional commitment that can enhance his skilled leadership.
Positions himself as the final authority after discussion, implying confidence in his decisions rather than openness to being corrected.
Enjoys a lively celebration with friends and family, engaging warmly with them by allowing roughhousing and laughter.
Displays a victorious look when being fined and suspended by the disciplinary committee, showing a possible defiance or lack of remorse.
Shows confidence and defiance by wanting to fight Mohammed Ali and embracing the moment with laughter and celebration among friends.
Maintains composure and a victorious look when faced with a disciplinary committee and a fine, initially smiling despite the suspension.
Smiles fading after the suspension ruling suggests momentary loss of control or inability to counter the penalty effectively.
Argues passionately to reduce the suspension of his captain, calling him the best player he's got.
Calls Peter Taylor late at night, seeking help and partnership to sort out a difficult situation.
Argues passionately against the suspension of his captain and tries to negotiate with the committee chairman, showing advocacy for his team.
After learning about the long suspension, immediately calls Peter Taylor to seek advice and support, showing awareness of his situation and willingness to seek help.
Expresses desperation and uncertainty about how to handle missing key players and the suspension, asking for help and advice openly.
Fails to come up with a clear plan during the phone call and shows some dependence on Peter Taylor for solutions, suggesting some doubt about his own immediate capability.
Winks discreetly at players McGovern and O'Hare, who respond positively.
Mentally refers to the players and club as HIS family and home, showing emotional connection.
Stares at the receiver after Taylor hangs up following a cold statement 'Each man for himself.'
Winks discreetly at McGovern and O'Hare who respond positively and get back to work, showing good rapport and team morale.
Walks along corridor with photos of his victories, signifying pride and confidence in his past achievements.
Approaches Mackay confidently to negotiate buying players, demonstrating initiative and leadership.
Negotiates firm but fair on player price, shakes hands with Mackay at deal completion.
Jokes with Mackay calling him 'fat bastard' but recalls improving his career, implying a mix of familiarity and sarcasm.
Suggests burning the desk as a way to 'exorcise' the place and himself, indicating frustration but no warmth or hostility.
Negotiates a player transfer deal firmly and confidently, refusing to overpay and settling on a price on his own terms.
Displays control of conversation and asserts authority in interactions with opponents or peers.
Manages relationships with rivals or former colleagues with a mix of respect and contempt, indicating strategic social awareness.
Summons Duncan Mackenzie abruptly by phone and orders him to come sign for Leeds United immediately.
Congratulates new signings and speaks of playing with flair, honour, and winning the right way, aiming to earn admiration from fans.
Immediately identifies Duncan Mackenzie, quickly arranges a meeting and signs him to Leeds United within a short time frame.
Congratulates new signings enthusiastically, establishes vision of playing with flair and honour.
Sets ambitious goals for the team to win major tournaments and aims to surpass previous records.
Demonstrates deep knowledge of his own achievements and uses them to motivate players.
Engages players as his eyes and ears in the dressing room to maintain control and gather information.
Uses somewhat condescending tone toward players and staff, possibly alienating them.
Calls Mackenzie 'Boss' and insists on making a clean team, asking to 'clear it out once and for all.'
Offers Mackenzie a drink and encourages him to 'drink up' before going to meet the press.
Dismisses need for detailed tactical preparation and rejects input from players, insisting on his authority with brusque language.
Says sorry to players after defeat and personally shakes hands and pats them on the back.
Dismisses preparation tactics used by predecessors, refuses to share detailed plans about opponents with players, and asserts his independence in training and team selection.
Acknowledges the team’s loss but maintains composure and encourages players by shaking hands and offering apologies.
Addresses the team sensitively and tactfully after a tough loss, reassuring and motivating them, refusing to blame their performance.
Claims to have spoken to the referee and promises to take the matter further, showing proactive and confident leadership.
Failing to maintain good rapport with Leeds players post-match who refuse his hand and walk away from him, indicating poor interpersonal effectiveness in this moment.
Left alone in the dressing-room, isolated from players after his speech, suggesting a lack of influence or respect in this situation.
Speaking bitterly on the phone late at night, worse for wear from alcohol, which could suggest impaired judgment or coping mechanisms under pressure.
Calls Don Revie late at night to confront him, revealing vulnerability but is rejected and insulted.
Informs Revie that his players won’t play for him, attempting to communicate honestly despite the tension.
Responds to Chairman's pragmatic request with sarcasm and refusal to compromise on team selection.
Claims sole credit for Derby County's success, dismissing previous contributions.
Does not respond to Peter Taylor's question and storms off, causing anxiety.
Leaps off bench in fury to shout abuse at a Leeds player for a rough tackle.
Claims full credit for Derby County’s rise and success, asserting his indispensable role.
Dismisses authority and the established hierarchy in football management, ignoring warnings from the chairman.
Reacts angrily and impulsively to a rough challenge in a game, shouting abuse at the referee.
Calls players like Hunter and Lorimer 'animals' and threatens legal action, reacts with anger to brutal tackles injuring his players.
Stares in horror at the injured players in the dressing-room, deeply affected by the carnage and injuries his team suffered.
Responds angrily to aggressive fouls against his team, calling opponents 'animal' and threatening legal action.
Unable to control his team's safety or ensure discipline as multiple players are seriously injured during the match.
Surveys the aftermath of the match and acknowledges the team's poor condition by sharing a knowing look with his assistant Taylor.
Presses his players/managers for honest feedback about team morale and attitudes.
Reacting with a violent outburst (throwing glass) in response to negative feedback.
Listening carefully and absorbing criticism rather than ignoring it.
Failing to effectively manage his emotional response to team concerns, potentially undermining leadership.
Refuses to allow players suspended or not performing well to receive complimentary cars, insulting them and punishing them by taking the cars away.
Refuses to allow senior players to receive complimentary cars when they are suspended and not performing well, emphasizing discipline and merit.
Handles the situation by confronting the representative and taking back the car keys indicating control and authority.
Dismisses the players' entitlement to perks despite their status, showing clear standards and expectations.
Displays a harsh, possibly alienating approach to motivate players (forcing them to walk to games) which could undermine team morale and cooperation.
Drives all night to be with his wife, kisses her, compliments her smell, and accepts her playful teasing.
Checks on his sons at night, responds patiently to request for a joke, and gently strokes his son's head.
Leaves hotel in Leeds to come home to his family despite early morning commitment.
Engages warmly and affectionately with his wife and children, showing emotional intelligence and presence of mind.
Continues stroking his son's hair as the child falls asleep, unaware; a tear runs down his cheek, showing vulnerability and affection.
Accepts the offer of a new car and smiles nervously, showing relief.
Responds politely and tries to explain despite a difficult start.
Admits the poor start openly and tries to explain his position calmly to Cussins.
Looks surprised and slightly unsettled when introduced to Martin Hughes and the Mercedes offer.
Smiles nervously and shows visible relief when discussion turns to easing tensions with players via the car gesture.
Visits his ill friend Peter Taylor in hospital and is visibly moved, managing a smile despite the grim surroundings.
Mimics and mocks the chairman's gagging order, showing a protective and loyal stance toward Taylor and their partnership.
Prepares a resigned letter citing a breakdown in communication but reassures Taylor he doesn't intend to resign, indicating care for his friend's feelings and their shared future.
Visits Peter Taylor in hospital, showing support despite difficult circumstances.
Calmly handles the tension of receiving a gagging order from management with wit and confidence.
Drafts a strongly worded resignation letter as a strategic move, indicating awareness of their leverage and situation.
Does not immediately resign despite conflict, showing prudence and realistic appraisal of their standing.
Insists on maintaining control over football decisions, refusing to work under a chairman who limits his authority.
Misidentifies the true source of conflict as the chairman Longson rather than focusing on the rival Revie and Leeds.
Storms into the boardroom confidently, confronting directors and asserting his indispensability to the club.
Pleading with the board not to accept their decision, expresses disbelief and frustration.
Appears isolated and speechless in a tense situation with the board, showing vulnerability.
Refuses to accept the board's decision and demands a settlement despite being told no.
Asserts his vision of creating a football dynasty at Derby County in front of the board.
Shows disbelief and inability to influence the board's decision despite his strong statements.
Players show unanimous support and respect for Clough, indicating trusting and good-natured relationships.
Expresses anger and betrayal at Dave Mackay's defection despite having supported him earlier, showing personal loyalty but also emotional intensity.
Plans legal action and supports players considering strike and protests, showing commitment to his team and cause.
Uses coarse language and displays a confrontational attitude in speech.
Does not recognize Mike Bamber as manager of Brighton and Hove Albion, showing a lack of knowledge about relevant figures.
Sits alone in the dugout during a game with a loud roar starting, suggesting readiness and confidence to lead the team.
Shows a stinging humiliation upon seeing the crowd's cheer for rival Don Revie and after the opposing team scores, indicating awareness of his current status and stakes.
Responds silently and does not argue when Manny Cussins orders him to the players' lounge for a meeting, implying either acceptance of consequences or possible uncertainty on how to respond.
Smiles under his breath and calls a player 'You bastard' when provoked.
Complies with management's order to leave the room quietly despite the situation.
Assures Jimmy Gordon that his job is safe despite turmoil.
Suggests Jimmy Gordon go home and do the same instead of staying.
Reacts with pain to criticism comparing him unfavorably to Don Revie ('a dagger in his heart').
Shows awareness of the situation by observing Don Revie welcomed by fans outside, indicating situational insight.
Responds to Jimmy Gordon's loyalty with a clear, firm suggestion to also leave, demonstrating decisiveness and confidence.
Contemplates severance pay immediately, showing practical consideration of consequences and self-interest.
Does not engage in argument when Bremner undermines his competence compared to Revie, instead turns away leading Jimmy Gordon, which can indicate emotional control but also potential avoidance.
Dismisses Brighton and Hove Albion as irrelevant, emphasizing 'we're from the North' and referring dismissively to 'Bloody Southerners'
Dismisses managing Brighton due to their location, division, and non-northern identity, showing reluctance to adapt or consider new opportunities.
Acknowledges potential opportunities at bigger clubs like Manchester United, Spurs, or England, indicating awareness of career possibilities.
Appears confident that his old club Derby might still reinstate him despite ongoing protests, showing possible overconfidence or misjudgment of situation.
Negotiates with Brighton Chairman Mike Bamber for a better salary and a bonus, showing confidence and awareness of financial standards.
Questions Mike Bamber's ability to afford first division wages, demonstrating prudence and financial awareness.
Agrees to a holiday before starting the job, indicating a confident and relaxed approach to transitions.
Cannot help smiling when greeted by Keith Archer.
Indignantly points to the newspaper to counter Archer's claim.
Questions Keith Archer about Leeds United's problems with a hint of humor and familiarity.
Suns himself calmly on the beach despite a tense situation, reads newspaper to stay informed, engages with Leeds United secretary Keith Archer confidently and with a smile.
Displays some indignant dismissal when told of Don Revie's job move, but uses the information from the paper to question Archer effectively.
Dismisses Brighton's loyalty and money, laughing dismissively at Pete's plea, calls Brighton 'fucking midgets', prioritizes personal ambition over promises.
Dismisses previous commitments and scruples about honor to pursue a better job at a top club and compete at the highest level.
Shows confidence and ambition about future achievements with a major club (mentioning Charity Shield and European Cup).
Disrespects a smaller club and its supporters/employees using derogatory language.
Is dismissive of concerns about loyalty and stability in favor of quicker success.
Insults Taylor harshly with personal attacks, calling him a parasite and nobody.
Attempts to stop Taylor as he walks away, calling after him.
Claims credit for past successes at Hartlepools and Derby, demonstrating confidence and a record of achievement.
Engages in heated, dismissive argument with Taylor, undermining a potential ally and possibly destabilizing relationships.
Displays strong self-confidence by aggressively defending himself against Taylor's criticisms.
Fails to acknowledge Taylor's contributions or self-awareness, suggesting possible blind spots or inflexibility.
Challenges the board members' approach and demands a high payout, asserting his worth.
Calls out the chairman's disrespectful behavior and defends his dignity.
Makes a sarcastic comment about the company car and his situation after dismissal.
Demands a high compensation package to leave, including salary for himself and assistant and income taxes for three years, showing confidence and awareness of his worth.
Calls out the chairman for unprofessional behavior of dismissing him behind his back, demonstrating assertiveness and ability to confront mismanagement.
Refuses to back down or appear intimidated when confronted aggressively by the board members, reinforcing his self-confidence and control of the situation.
Responds to Mackenzie supportively, calling him 'Good lad.'
Shakes Clarke's hand before leaving, indicating polite recognition.
Smiles and shows vulnerability when speaking to Mitchell, asking him to 'go easy on me' and calling him 'good lad.'
Expresses shock and disappointment but speaks diplomatically about Don Revie's longer tenure.
Calls the interview a set-up and insults the crew ('You bastards!').
Responds calmly and confidently in a tense public interview despite being publicly sacked and confronted by a rival.
Accurately identifies the interview as a set-up, showing awareness of the political and social context.
Expresses shock but maintains composure and even a measure of sarcasm when addressing the situation.
Thanked Revie when not called by surname, showing politeness.
Openly called Revie's players 'dirty' and wished Leeds relegated.
Admitted taking the Leeds managerial job because it was the best job.
Expressed confidence and ambition about winning league and Europe better than Revie.
Claims to be a warm man and an idealist, contrasts himself with Don Revie's coldness.
Admits players would not have let him give them personal care, implying a distance or lack of attempt to connect.
Describes arrival at Leeds as marked by Revie's coldness and lack of warmth permeating the club.
Focuses on personal vendetta and conflict rather than reconciliation or understanding with Revie.
Declares confidently that he can lose fewer matches and play attractive, clean football without cheating.
Reflects on differences in style and personality with Don Revie, portraying himself as warm and idealistic but possibly naive.
Admits players would never have let him 'massage' them, indicating a lack of effort or connection with players compared to Revie's approach.
Focuses on personal vendetta against Revie rather than considering the club or players, implying a potential neglect of professional priorities.
Accuses Revie of refusing to shake his hand and looking down on him, implying personal grievance.
Blurts out 'Well, you certainly know it NOW' unintentionally loud, revealing frustration.
Given the strongest team in British football, Leeds United, takes them to the bottom of the first division.
Confidently challenges Donald Revie to see their relative success in one and five years.
Sitting hollow-eyed and wishing to disappear after public confrontation and humiliation.
Shows self-awareness and humor about his own mistakes and immaturity in a candid conversation with his sons.
Invites the boys on a trip to the seaside, showing inclusive and friendly behavior.
Comes to Peter Taylor's house and initially resists groveling but ultimately gets on his knees and apologizes sincerely, showing humility and vulnerability.
Admits failure quickly (44 days out), goes directly to Peter Taylor to seek help and reconciliation, ultimately humbling himself and apologizing unreservedly.
Previously got kicked out after 44 days, implying failure in a competence-related context.
Initially rejects Peter Taylor's plea to reconcile with a harsh 'Fuck off..!'
Eventually embraces Peter Taylor and expresses love despite their troubled relationship
Acknowledges his harmful tendencies openly to Taylor and questions if Taylor prefers to be without him
Shows emotional vulnerability and admits dependence on Peter Taylor despite pride.
Reunites with Peter Taylor leading to major career successes including winning the European Cup twice with Nottingham Forest.
Eventually falls out with Peter Taylor again, indicating persistent relational difficulties.
